interactive.title: PRCR Bird's Eye
interactive.description: An application for use by Raleigh Parks' planning staff to view parks and greenway areas using the oblique imagery layer provided through Microsoft's Bing Maps.

interactive.title: Raleigh Property Query Tool
interactive.description: An application for use by Raleigh Parks' planning staff to help search for potential land acquisition opportunities.

interactive.title: Kentucky Population Projections
interactive.description: An interactive county-by-county look at population projections and trends in Kentucky from 2010-2040  based on data from the Kentucky State Data Center.

interactive.title: Busiest Container Ports, 2004-2019
interactive.description: Created while taking a course in interactive cartography at the Universiy of Wisconsin, this application uses an examination of container port business in order to explore how to use JavaScript to give users the ability to filter the features on the map by multiple dimensions.

interactive.title: Raleigh Park Amenities Finder
interactive.description: This map shows the location of all of Raleigh's parks with an option to filter based on park type and amenities.

cartography.title: Raleigh Park Access
cartography.description: This longform infographic examines 10 minute walk access to parks in Raleigh, NC and proposes a social equity approach to prioritizing access improvements.

cartography.title: Yellow-Bellied Sapsucker Seasonal Range
cartography.description: I created this map depicting the seasonal range of the yellow-bellied sapsucker while participating in the 2019 30 Day Map Challenge. The day's theme was "yellow".

cartography.title: Old North State Bike Race Map
cartography.description: Created for as part of a cartography assignment, this map plots a 3 part, 21 stage, 2,100 mile fictional bike race that criss-crosses North Carolina.

cartography.title: Citrix Cycle Raleigh Bike Share Rides
cartography.description: I created this map depicting the monthly rides of Raleigh's Citrix Cycle bike share while participating in the 2019 30 Day Map Challenge. The day's theme was "lines".

data.title: Raleigh Parks Level of Service Profiler
data.description: I developed this application as a demonstration of how the parks level of service analysis my colleagues and I had developed could be visualized and integrated with other datasets relevant to park planning.

data.title: Raleigh Center Analysis
data.description: This analysis started with a question from a colleague: 'Where is the center of Raleigh?' The definition of 'center,' especially for complex shapes like city boundaries, can be a bit thorny. Rather than answer the question definitively, I used the interacitve notebook format of Observable to explore the messiness of centrality.

data.title: GoRaleigh Bus Shelter Analysis
data.description: In working on the 2019 30 Day Map Challenge, I carried out an analysis of bus stops for the GoRaleigh bus system, particularly focusing on the status of shelters at those stops. This involved pulling together data from multiple data sources and carrying out some programmatic (Python) conflation to create a single dataset for visualization and analysis.

data.title: Raleigh Playground Gap Analysis
data.description: The application here is a result of an analysis requested by a colleague of mine. In particular, they were interested in seeing where there might be opportunities to partner with Wake County Public Schools to fill gaps in walkable access to playgrounds throughout Raleigh.

experiments.title: Greenway Lightsabers
experiments.description: The ArcGIS API for JavaScript 4.18 introduced the ability to apply CSS effects and Photoshop-like blend modes to feature layers. In 2021, access to these features was added to the ArcGIS Online Map Viewer. This experiment uses the Map Viewer to apply blend modes, layer effects, and group layers to define a glowing style to Raleigh's Greenway Trail dataset in order to give the impression that those trails are illuminating the underlying imagery basemap. I then use the ArcGIS API for JavaScript to load the map and manipulate the layer effects to generate a more organic, pulsing glow on the greenway trails.

experiments.title: Client-side Straight-line Distance to Center of Nearest Park
experiments.description: This experiment explores how turfJS can be used to pull together multiple datasets into something totally different. First, turfJS to creates a bounding box based on the extent of the Raleigh planning jurisdiction. Then turfJS creates a grid that fits into that extent. Next, turfJS generates centroids for Raleigh parks and the grid squares. Finally turfJS is used to find the distance to the closest park centroid for each grid square.

experiments.title: Clip and Dissolve Lines by a Polygon with Turf
experiments.description: While clipping a line by a polygon is simple with most any desktop GIS software, PostGIS, or Python, it is less straightforward to do so with JavaScript. In this notebook I work through an approach to clipping lines by polygons using a combination of spatial functions available in Turf.

experiments.title: 54 Square Mile Raleigh
experiments.description: A discussion popped up in Raleigh about population density at the city's founding in the 18th century versus today. By one local's calculation, if the city had maintained it's density at founding through to today, the entire Raleigh population could fit into a 54 square mile area. This map seeks to make that area visible. With some basic geometry and help of the Turf JavaScript library, I generated both a 54 square mile circle and square centered on Raleigh's original center at the North Carolina Capitol.
